document: Harpa, a stunning concert hall and conference center located in Reykjavik, Iceland, is a true architectural marvel. Designed by the renowned Danish firm, Henning Larsen Architects, in collaboration with the talented Danish-Icelandic artist, Olafur Eliasson, the building's exterior is adorned with a captivating colored glass facade. This unique feature draws inspiration from Iceland's breathtaking basalt landscape. Combining a steel framework with an array of geometric shaped glass panels in various vibrant colors, Harpa stands as a modern masterpiece that beautifully captures the imagination of all who encounter it.
noref_document: Harpa is a concert hall and conference center located in Reykjavík, Iceland. Designed by Olafur Eliasson and Henning Larsen Architects, it is a mesmerizing architectural marvel that has become an iconic landmark in the city. Harpa offers a unique blend of modern design and natural elements inspired by Iceland's rugged landscape. With its distinctive glass facade resembling a honeycomb, Harpa is not only visually stunning but also acoustically exceptional. Housing the Iceland Symphony Orchestra and the Icelandic Opera, it serves as a hub for world-class performances and cultural events. The concert hall's interior features multiple performance spaces, including a grand concert hall, a smaller recital hall, and a flexible theater. Harpa also houses exhibition spaces, shops, restaurants, and hosts a variety of conferences, making it a multi-functional and vibrant cultural center.
summary:
Harpa (Icelandic pronunciation: [ˈhar̥pa], English: Harp) is a concert hall and conference centre in Reykjavík, Iceland. The opening concert was held on May 4, 2011. The building features a distinctive colored glass facade inspired by the basalt landscape of Iceland.


== History ==
Harpa was designed by the Danish firm Henning Larsen Architects in co-operation with Danish-Icelandic artist Olafur Eliasson. The structure consists of a steel framework clad with geometric shaped glass panels of different colours.

document: Breaking Bad, the critically acclaimed American crime drama television series created by Vince Gilligan for AMC, takes viewers on a thrilling and suspenseful journey. Set and filmed in Albuquerque, New Mexico, the show revolves around the life of Walter White, a high-school chemistry teacher faced with a devastating diagnosis of stage-three lung cancer. Struggling with financial difficulties and a desire to provide for his family's future, Walter delves into a dangerous world of crime. Teaming up with his former student, Jesse Pinkman, they embark on a risky venture of producing and distributing methamphetamine. As the series unfolds, the audience is taken on a rollercoaster ride of intense character development, navigating the treacherous criminal underworld. Breaking Bad premiered in 2008 and captivated audiences for five seasons, with an ensemble cast including Bryan Cranston as Walter White, Aaron Paul as Jesse Pinkman, and a host of other talented actors portraying integral characters such as family members, lawyers, investigators, and drug kingpins.
noref_document: Breaking Bad is a critically acclaimed American television series created by Vince Gilligan. The show follows the story of Walter White, a high school chemistry teacher turned methamphetamine manufacturer, and his former student, Jesse Pinkman, as they navigate the dangerous underworld of illegal drug production in Albuquerque, New Mexico. Known for its compelling storytelling, complex characters, and dark humor, Breaking Bad explores themes of morality, greed, and the consequences of one's actions. The series garnered widespread praise for its writing, acting, and visual style, establishing itself as one of the greatest television dramas of all time.
summary:
Breaking Bad is  an American crime drama television series created and produced by Vince Gilligan for AMC. Set and filmed in Albuquerque, New Mexico, the series follows Walter White (Bryan Cranston), an underpaid, overqualified, and dispirited high-school chemistry teacher who is struggling with a recent diagnosis of stage-three lung cancer. White turns to a life of crime and partners with a former student, Jesse Pinkman (Aaron Paul), to produce and distribute methamphetamine to secure his family's financial future before he dies, while navigating the dangers of the criminal underworld. Breaking Bad premiered on AMC on January 20, 2008, and concluded on September 29, 2013, after five seasons consisting of 62 episodes.
Among the show's co-stars are Anna Gunn and RJ Mitte as Walter's wife Skyler and son Walter Jr., and Betsy Brandt and Dean Norris as Skyler's sister Marie Schrader and her husband Hank, a DEA agent. Others include Bob Odenkirk as Walter's and Jesse's lawyer Saul Goodman, Jonathan Banks as private investigator and fixer Mike Ehrmantraut, and Giancarlo Esposito as drug kingpin Gus Fring.

document: The Office is an iconic American mockumentary sitcom that takes viewers into the amusing and sometimes cringeworthy world of office life. Set at the Scranton branch of the fictional Dunder Mifflin Paper Company in Pennsylvania, the show offers a hilarious and relatable glimpse into the everyday work lives of a diverse group of employees. Airing from 2005 to 2013, The Office spanned a total of nine seasons and quickly became a beloved television series. Created by Ricky Gervais and Stephen Merchant, the show's adaptation for American audiences was masterfully done by Greg Daniels, a seasoned writer known for his work on popular shows like Saturday Night Live, King of the Hill, and The Simpsons. Co-produced by Daniels' Deedle-Dee Productions and Reveille Productions, in association with Universal Television, The Office featured an all-star cast and successfully blended humor with insightful commentary on office politics and relationships. It quickly gained a devoted fanbase and solidified its place as a modern classic in the sitcom genre.
noref_document: The Office is a widely popular American television series that was adapted from the original British version. Premiering in 2005, the show is a mockumentary-style sitcom that revolves around the daily lives of office employees working at Dunder Mifflin Paper Company. Set in Scranton, Pennsylvania, the series humorously explores the dynamics of a quirky and diverse group of employees through their interactions, pranks, and the underlying tensions amongst them. With a talented ensemble cast led by Steve Carell as Michael Scott, the bumbling yet well-meaning regional manager, The Office captivated audiences with its relatable characters, sharp writing, and distinctive documentary-style format. The series continues to enjoy a dedicated fanbase even after its conclusion in 2013, thanks to its endearing characters and binge-worthy storytelling.
summary: The Office is an American mockumentary sitcom television series that depicts the everyday work lives of office employees at the Scranton, Pennsylvania, branch of the fictional Dunder Mifflin Paper Company. It aired on NBC from March 24, 2005, to May 16, 2013, spanning a total of nine seasons. Based on the 2001–2003 BBC series of the same name created by Ricky Gervais and Stephen Merchant, it was adapted for American television by Greg Daniels, a veteran writer for Saturday Night Live, King of the Hill, and The Simpsons. It was co-produced by Daniels' Deedle-Dee Productions and Reveille Productions (later Shine America), in association with Universal Television. The original executive producers were Daniels, Gervais, Merchant, Howard Klein, and Ben Silverman, with numerous others being promoted in later seasons.

document: Friends, created by David Crane and Marta Kauffman, is an iconic American television sitcom that aired on NBC from September 22, 1994, to May 6, 2004. Lasting for ten memorable seasons, the show follows the lives of six friends in their 20s and 30s who reside in Manhattan, New York City. With an ensemble cast featuring Jennifer Aniston, Courteney Cox, Lisa Kudrow, Matt LeBlanc, Matthew Perry, and David Schwimmer, Friends became a global phenomenon, captivating audiences with its relatable characters, witty humor, and heartfelt moments. Originally developed under the working title Insomnia Cafe, the show underwent various script rewrites and title changes before the series was eventually named Friends. The original executive producers, Kevin S. Bright, Kauffman, and Crane, played instrumental roles in shaping the beloved sitcom.
noref_document: "F.R.I.E.N.D.S" is a popular American sitcom that aired from 1994 to 2004. Created by David Crane and Marta Kauffman, the show revolves around a group of six friends living in Manhattan, New York. It features a blend of comedy, romance, and drama as it explores the ups and downs of their personal and professional lives. The central characters, Monica, Ross, Rachel, Chandler, Joey, and Phoebe, face relatable situations, navigating through careers, relationships, and the challenges of adulthood. With its iconic catchphrases, memorable quirks, and well-developed characters, "F.R.I.E.N.D.S" has become a cultural phenomenon and continues to captivate audiences worldwide.
summary:
Friends is an American television sitcom created by David Crane and Marta Kauffman, which aired on NBC from September 22, 1994, to May 6, 2004, lasting ten seasons. With an ensemble cast starring Jennifer Aniston, Courteney Cox, Lisa Kudrow, Matt LeBlanc, Matthew Perry and David Schwimmer, the show revolves around six friends in their 20s and 30s who live in Manhattan, New York City. The original executive producers were Kevin S. Bright, Kauffman, and Crane.
Kauffman and Crane began developing Friends under the working title Insomnia Cafe between November and December 1993. They presented the idea to Bright, and together they pitched a seven-page treatment of the show to NBC. After several script rewrites and changes, including title changes to Six of One and Friends Like Us, the series was finally named Friends.

document: How I Met Your Mother (often abbreviated as HIMYM) is an American sitcom that aired from September 19, 2005 to March 31, 2014. Created by Craig Thomas and Carter Bays for CBS, the series revolves around the life of the main character, Ted Mosby, and his group of friends in Manhattan, New York City. A unique aspect of the show is its framing device, with Ted recounting the events that led him to meet his children's mother, starting from September 2005 and spanning until May 2013. How I Met Your Mother was a joint production by Bays & Thomas Productions and 20th Century Fox Television, and it was syndicated by 20th Television (now Disney-ABC Domestic Television). The series drew inspiration from Thomas and Bays' own friendship during their time in New York, and Pamela Fryman directed the vast majority of its episodes, directing 196 out of 208.
noref_document: "How I Met Your Mother" is a popular American sitcom that aired from 2005 to 2014. Set in New York City, the show follows a group of friends and their romantic escapades, primarily through the eyes of the protagonist, Ted Mosby. The series gained a large fan base due to its witty humor, compelling narrative structure, and the iconic catchphrases it introduced, such as "legen... wait for it... dary." "How I Met Your Mother" also incorporated storytelling techniques, often using flashbacks and flash-forwards, as Ted recounts the story of how he met his children's mother. With its clever writing, relatable characters, and memorable moments, the show remains a beloved part of modern television culture.
summary:
How I Met Your Mother (often abbreviated as HIMYM) is an American sitcom, created by Craig Thomas and Carter Bays for CBS. The series, which aired from September 19, 2005 to March 31, 2014, follows the main character, Ted Mosby, and his group of friends in New York City's Manhattan. As a framing device, Ted, in 2030, recounts to his son, Luke, and daughter, Penny, the events from September 2005 to May 2013 that led him to meet their mother. How I Met Your Mother was a joint production by Bays & Thomas Productions and 20th Century Fox Television, and syndicated by 20th Television (now Disney-ABC Domestic Television).
The series was loosely inspired by Thomas and Bays' friendship when they both lived in New York. The vast majority of the episodes (196 out of 208) were directed by Pamela Fryman.

document: Parks and Recreation, a beloved American political satire sitcom created by Greg Daniels and Michael Schur, aired from 2009 to 2015, captivating audiences with its witty humor and unique mockumentary style. The show revolves around Leslie Knope, played by Amy Poehler, an optimistic and determined bureaucrat working in the Parks Department of Pawnee, Indiana. With a talented ensemble cast including Rashida Jones, Aziz Ansari, Nick Offerman, Aubrey Plaza, Chris Pratt, and many more, the series skillfully combines comedy and satire to explore the inner workings of local government and the quirky dynamics of small-town life. Although the show concluded in 2015, a special reunion episode in 2020 brought back the beloved characters, reminding fans of the delightful charm that Parks and Recreation has become known for.
noref_document: Parks and Recreation is an American political satire television sitcom that aired from 2009 to 2015. Created by Greg Daniels and Michael Schur, the show explores the daily operations of the Parks Department in the fictional town of Pawnee, Indiana. Led by the enthusiastic and eager-to-please Leslie Knope, the department faces various challenges while striving to improve the city's parks and recreational activities. With its witty humor, endearing characters, and clever storytelling, Parks and Recreation has garnered a strong fan base and critical acclaim, becoming a beloved and influential TV series.
summary: Parks and Recreation (also known as Parks and Rec) is an American political satire mockumentary sitcom television series created by Greg Daniels and Michael Schur. The series aired on NBC from April 9, 2009, to February 24, 2015, for 125 episodes, over seven seasons. A special reunion episode aired on April 30, 2020. The series stars Amy Poehler as Leslie Knope, a perky, mid-level bureaucrat in the Parks Department of the fictional town of Pawnee, Indiana. The ensemble and supporting cast features Rashida Jones as Ann Perkins, Paul Schneider as Mark Brendanawicz, Aziz Ansari as Tom Haverford, Nick Offerman as Ron Swanson, Aubrey Plaza as April Ludgate, Chris Pratt as Andy Dwyer, Adam Scott as Ben Wyatt, Rob Lowe as Chris Traeger, Jim O'Heir as Garry "Jerry" Gergich, Retta as Donna Meagle, and Billy Eichner as Craig Middlebrooks.

document: 30 Rock, the American satirical sitcom television series created by Tina Fey, aired on NBC from October 11, 2006, to January 31, 2013. Drawing from Fey's experiences as head writer for Saturday Night Live, the show takes viewers behind the scenes of a fictional live sketch comedy show, set to air on NBC. The series is named after 30 Rockefeller Plaza in New York City, where NBC Studios and Saturday Night Live are based. Produced by Lorne Michaels's Broadway Video and Fey's Little Stranger, in association with NBCUniversal, 30 Rock episodes were shot in a single-camera setup, except for two live episodes. The series boasts a stellar cast including Alec Baldwin, Tracy Morgan, Jane Krakowski, Jack McBrayer, and more. Notably, 30 Rock employs surreal humor to satirize the intricate corporate structure of NBC, General Electric, and Comcast, its parent companies.
noref_document: 30 Rock is a landmark television series that aired from 2006 to 2013. Created by the talented comedic mind of Tina Fey, the show takes its name from the iconic address of the NBC Studios located in New York City. Known for its sharp writing and brilliant ensemble cast, 30 Rock delves into the chaotic world of producing a live sketch comedy show, fictionalizing the ups and downs of working behind the scenes at a television network. Fey's character, Liz Lemon, serves as the head writer for the show within the show, offering a humorous and relatable glimpse into the challenges and absurdities of the entertainment industry. With its clever wit, memorable characters, and satirical commentary, 30 Rock has solidified its place as one of the greatest sitcoms of all time.
summary: 30 Rock is an American satirical sitcom television series created by Tina Fey that originally aired on NBC from October 11, 2006, to January 31, 2013. The series, based on Fey's experiences as head writer for Saturday Night Live, takes place behind the scenes of a fictional live sketch comedy show depicted as airing on NBC. The series's name refers to 30 Rockefeller Plaza in New York City, where the NBC Studios are located and where Saturday Night Live is written, produced, and performed. The series was produced by Lorne Michaels's Broadway Video (which also produces Saturday Night Live) and Fey's Little Stranger, in association with NBCUniversal.30 Rock episodes were produced in a single-camera setup (with the exception of the two live episodes that were produced in the multiple-camera setup) and were filmed in New York. The pilot episode premiered on October 11, 2006, and seven seasons followed. The series stars Fey with a supporting cast that includes Alec Baldwin, Tracy Morgan, Jane Krakowski, Jack McBrayer, Scott Adsit, Judah Friedlander, Katrina Bowden, Keith Powell, Lonny Ross, John Lutz, Kevin Brown, Grizz Chapman, and Maulik Pancholy.Tonally, 30 Rock uses surreal humor to parody the complex corporate structure of NBC and its parent companies General Electric and Comcast.

document: Mad Men is an intriguing American period drama television series that aired from 2007 to 2015. Created by Matthew Weiner and produced by Lionsgate Television, the show takes place from 1960 to 1970 and revolves around the advertising industry. Starting at the fictional Sterling Cooper agency in Manhattan's Madison Avenue, the storyline later shifts to the new firm of Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce. The phrase "Mad men" was reportedly coined by advertisers on Madison Avenue in the 1950s to refer to themselves. The series follows the charismatic advertising executive Don Draper, played by Jon Hamm, and his journey as the talented creative director at Sterling Cooper.
noref_document: Mad Men is an American television drama series that depicts the advertising industry during the 1960s and focuses on the lives of the men and women working at the fictional Sterling Cooper advertising agency on Madison Avenue in New York City. The show explores the inner workings of the advertising world, highlighting its competitive nature, workplace dynamics, and the personal struggles of the characters. Set against the backdrop of the changing social and cultural landscape of the era, Mad Men immerses viewers in the glamorous yet tumultuous world of Madison Avenue advertising.
summary:
Mad Men  is an American period drama television series created by Matthew Weiner and produced by Lionsgate Television. It ran on the cable network AMC from July 19, 2007, to May 17, 2015, lasting for seven seasons and 92 episodes. The show is set from March 1960 to November 1970.
Mad Men begins at the fictional Sterling Cooper advertising agency on Madison Avenue in Manhattan, New York City, and continues at the new firm of Sterling Cooper Draper Pryce (later named Sterling Cooper & Partners) near the Time-Life Building at 1271 Sixth Avenue. According to the pilot episode, the phrase "Mad men" was a slang term coined in the 1950s by advertisers working on Madison Avenue to refer to themselves, "Mad" being short for "Madison" (in reality, the only documented use of the phrase from that time may have been in the late-1950s writings of James Kelly, an advertising executive and writer).The series's main character is the charismatic advertising executive Don Draper (played by Jon Hamm), who is initially the talented creative director at Sterling Cooper.

document: Dexter, the critically acclaimed American crime drama television series, captivated audiences from 2006 to 2013. Set in the vibrant city of Miami, the show revolves around the complex life of Dexter Morgan, a forensic technician specializing in bloodstain pattern analysis for the fictional Miami Metro Police Department. But beneath his seemingly ordinary job, Dexter hides a dark secret - he is a vigilante serial killer. Fueled by a desire to bring justice to those who have escaped punishment, he hunts down murderers who have evaded the grasp of the flawed justice system. The series, adapted from Jeff Lindsay's novel Darkly Dreaming Dexter, introduces viewers to a thrilling narrative that often diverges from the original source material, captivating fans with its twist-filled storylines and the riveting performance of Michael C. Hall in the lead role.
noref_document: "Dexter" is an acclaimed television series that aired from 2006 to 2021. It revolves around the fascinating character of Dexter Morgan, a blood-spatter analyst by day and a methodical serial killer by night. Set in Miami, the show presents a gripping storyline filled with suspense, crime, and moral ambiguity. Dexter's ability to blend seamlessly into society while satisfying his dark desires adds a unique twist to the traditional crime drama genre. With its complex characters, intricate plotlines, and exploration of themes such as vigilantism and the nature of evil, "Dexter" has garnered a dedicated fanbase and remains a prominent piece in the history of television.
summary: Dexter is an American crime drama television series that aired on Showtime from October 1, 2006, to September 22, 2013. Set in Miami, the series centers on Dexter Morgan (Michael C. Hall), a forensic technician specializing in bloodstain pattern analysis for the fictional Miami Metro Police Department, who leads a secret parallel life as a vigilante serial killer, hunting down murderers who have not been adequately punished by the justice system due to corruption or legal technicalities. The show's first season was derived from the novel Darkly Dreaming Dexter (2004), the first in a series of novels by Jeff Lindsay. It was adapted for television by James Manos Jr., who wrote the first episode. Subsequent seasons evolved independently of Lindsay's works.

document: BlackBerry OS, developed by BlackBerry Limited, was a proprietary mobile operating system for BlackBerry smartphones. It provided multitasking, specialized input devices, and support for corporate email through Java Micro Edition MIDP. With wireless activation and synchronization, users could seamlessly connect with Microsoft Exchange, Lotus Domino, or Novell GroupWise email, calendar, tasks, notes, and contacts using the BlackBerry Enterprise Server. The platform also supported WAP 2.0. Wireless carriers offered over-the-air software updates for BlackBerry OS.
noref_document: BlackBerry OS is a mobile operating system developed by BlackBerry Limited for its line of smartphones. Initially launched in 1999, BlackBerry OS became known for its strong focus on secure communication and its iconic physical keyboards. It offered users a range of features such as push email, messaging, and internet browsing. Over the years, BlackBerry OS evolved to include additional functionalities like social media integration and app support. However, with the rise of iOS and Android, BlackBerry OS faced tough competition and struggled to maintain its market share. Eventually, the company decided to discontinue the operating system in favor of adopting Android for its newer devices.
summary:
BlackBerry OS is a discontinued proprietary mobile operating system developed by Canadian company BlackBerry Limited for its BlackBerry line of smartphone handheld devices. The operating system provides multitasking and supports specialized input devices adopted by BlackBerry for use in its handhelds, particularly the trackwheel, trackball, and most recently, the trackpad and touchscreen.
The BlackBerry platform natively supports corporate email, through Java Micro Edition MIDP 1.0 and, more recently, a subset of MIDP 2.0, which allows complete wireless activation and synchronization with Microsoft Exchange, Lotus Domino, or Novell GroupWise email, calendar, tasks, notes and contacts, when used with BlackBerry Enterprise Server.  The operating system also supports WAP 2.0.
Updates to the operating system were automatically available from wireless carriers that supported the BlackBerry over the air software loading (OTASL) service.

document: Windows Phone, developed by Microsoft, was a family of mobile operating systems aimed at the consumer market. With its launch in October 2010, it introduced a new user interface inspired by the Metro design language. Unlike its predecessor, Windows Mobile, Windows Phone targeted consumers instead of enterprises. In 2012, Windows Phone 8 was released, which replaced the Windows CE-based kernel with the Windows NT kernel, similar to the one used in PC versions of Windows. Despite the improvements, this upgrade rendered Windows Phone 7 devices incompatible with the new OS. Nonetheless, it still supported apps originally developed for Windows Phone 7.
noref_document: Windows Phone was a mobile operating system developed by Microsoft. It was launched in October 2010 as the successor to Windows Mobile, and aimed to provide a unique and user-friendly experience for smartphones. Windows Phone featured a distinctive tile-based interface known as the "Metro" design language, which focused on simplicity and visual appeal. The operating system offered a wide range of features such as live tiles, seamless integration with Microsoft services, and a fluid and responsive user interface. Despite its innovative design and capabilities, Windows Phone faced tough competition from Android and iOS, and struggled to gain significant market share. Microsoft eventually announced the discontinuation of Windows Phone in 2017, shifting their focus towards other platforms.
summary: Windows Phone (WP) is a discontinued family of mobile operating systems developed by Microsoft for smartphones as the replacement successor to Windows Mobile and Zune. Windows Phone featured a new user interface derived from the Metro design language. Unlike Windows Mobile, it was primarily aimed at the consumer market rather than the enterprise market.It was first launched in October 2010 with Windows Phone 7. Windows Phone 8 succeeded it in 2012, replacing the Windows CE-based kernel of Windows Phone 7 with the Windows NT kernel used by the PC versions of Windows (and, in particular, a large amount of internal components from Windows 8). Due to these changes, the OS was incompatible with all existing Windows Phone 7 devices, although it still supported apps originally developed for Windows Phone 7.

document: Google Reader, an RSS/Atom feed aggregator, was a beloved platform that offered users a centralized hub to access and read their favorite publications and websites. Developed by Google engineer Chris Wetherell, it was launched in 2005 and quickly gained popularity, becoming a key tool for many who relied on it for their daily news consumption. Moreover, Google Reader served as a foundation for various programs that utilized it to deliver timely and relevant information to users. However, with declining usage, Google made the difficult decision to shut down Google Reader in 2013, leaving behind nostalgic memories and a void in the RSS reader market.
noref_document: Google Reader was a web-based aggregator launched by Google in October 2005 that allowed users to subscribe to and read RSS and Atom feeds. It became popular among users who wanted to easily keep track of updates from their favorite websites and blogs in one central location. With Google Reader, individuals were able to organize their subscriptions into folders, tag articles for future reference, and even share interesting content with their friends. However, despite its initial success, Google decided to shut down Google Reader in July 2013, much to the disappointment of its dedicated user base.
summary:
Google Reader was an RSS/Atom feed aggregator operated by Google. It was created in early 2005 by Google engineer Chris Wetherell and launched on October 7, 2005, through Google Labs. Google Reader grew in popularity to support a number of programs which used it as a platform for serving news and information to users. Google closed Google Reader on July 1, 2013, citing declining use.


== History ==
In early 2001, software engineer Chris Wetherell began a project he called "JavaCollect" that served as a news portal based on web feeds.

document: Microsoft Groove, previously known as Xbox Music and Zune Music Pass, was a popular audio player software that came bundled with Windows operating systems. Alongside the software, Microsoft also offered a music streaming service called Groove Music Pass, accessible on various platforms including Windows, Xbox consoles, Windows Phone, Android, and iOS. Boasting an extensive catalogue of more than 50 million tracks, Groove Music offered users a vast selection of music to enjoy. However, Groove Music Pass was officially discontinued on December 31, 2017, with the Android and iOS versions of the Groove Music app following suit in December 2018, limiting the player to its native Microsoft Store. With the release of Windows 10 and subsequently Windows 11, Groove Music was succeeded by the Media Player, which was gradually rolled out to Windows 10 users between January and June 2023.
noref_document: Microsoft Groove, previously known as Xbox Music and Zune Music, is a digital music streaming service developed by Microsoft. It provides users with access to a vast collection of songs from various genres and artists, allowing them to stream music online or download it for offline listening. With a user-friendly interface and intuitive features, Microsoft Groove offers playlist creation, personalized recommendations, and the ability to sync music across multiple devices. Additionally, the service integrates seamlessly with Microsoft's other platforms and devices, such as Windows, Xbox, and Windows Phone, ensuring a unified music experience for its users.
summary:
Groove Music (formerly Xbox Music or Zune Music Pass) is a discontinued audio player software application included with Windows 8, Windows 8.1, Windows 10 and Windows 11.
The app is also associated with a now-discontinued music streaming service, Groove Music Pass, which was supported across Windows, Xbox video game consoles, Windows Phone, as well as Android and iOS. As of 2014, The Groove catalogue had over 50 million tracks. Its subscription service Groove Music Pass was officially discontinued on December 31, 2017, and the Android and iOS versions of the Groove Music app were discontinued in December 2018, restricting the player to its native Microsoft Store base.
Groove Music was superseded by Media Player in Windows 10 and Windows 11. The update was rolled out to Windows 10 users between January and June 2023.

document: iPhoto, a digital photograph manipulation software application developed by Apple Inc, became a prominent tool for Mac users from 2002 to 2015. It offered a range of features including importing, organizing, editing, printing, and sharing digital photos. Announced at Macworld 2002 alongside significant updates and announcements for Apple products, iPhoto soon became a part of the iLife suite of digital media management applications. In 2012, Apple introduced an iOS-native version of iPhoto, aligning it with the growing popularity of mobile devices. However, in 2014, Apple decided to discontinue iPhoto and focus on developing their new Photos app. This transition was completed in 2015 with the release of OS X Yosemite 10.10.3, which included the new Photos app.
noref_document: iPhoto is a digital photograph manipulation software application developed by Apple Inc. It was first released in 2002 as part of the iLife suite of digital media management applications. iPhoto allowed users to import, organize, edit, print, and share their photos in a seamless and user-friendly way. It featured a range of powerful tools, including basic editing functionality, filters, and effects, making it a popular choice among Mac users for managing their photo libraries. iPhoto was later replaced by the new Photos app in 2015, which offered even more advanced features and integration with cloud storage services.
summary:
iPhoto is a discontinued digital photograph manipulation software application developed by Apple Inc. It was included with every Mac computer from 2002 to 2015, when it was replaced with Apple's Photos application. Originally sold as part of the iLife suite of digital media management applications, iPhoto is able to import, organize, edit, print and share digital photos.


== History ==
iPhoto was announced at Macworld 2002, during which Steve Jobs (then-CEO of Apple) also announced that macOS would be the default operating system on new Macs, and revealed new iMac and iBook models.On March 7, 2012, Apple CEO Tim Cook announced an iOS-native version of iPhoto alongside the third-generation iPad.On June 27, 2014, Apple announced that they would cease development of iPhoto and work on a transition to their new Photos app. On February 5, 2015 Apple included a preview of Photos with a beta release of OS X Yosemite.On April 8, 2015, Apple released OS X Yosemite 10.10.3, which included the new Photos app.

document: Internet Explorer, formerly known as Microsoft Internet Explorer, is a series of graphical web browsers developed by Microsoft. Once a popular choice for Windows operating systems, Internet Explorer has now been discontinued for most modern Windows editions. However, it continues to be supported on certain editions such as Windows 10 LTSB/LTSC. Initially released in 1995 as part of the Plus! for Windows 95 add-on package, later versions were made available as free downloads or in-service packs and included in OEM service releases of Windows. At its peak, Microsoft invested over US$100 million per year on Internet Explorer, involving more than 1,000 individuals in the project by 1999.
noref_document: Internet Explorer is a web browser developed by Microsoft. It was first released in 1995 and quickly became one of the most popular browsers in the world. Internet Explorer played a significant role in the early days of the Internet, providing users with a simple and intuitive interface to navigate the web. Despite its initial success, Internet Explorer faced criticism for its slow performance and lack of compatibility with modern web standards. As a result, Microsoft discontinued Internet Explorer in 2015 and replaced it with Microsoft Edge. However, Internet Explorer's impact on shaping the internet and its role in introducing many users to the online world cannot be underestimated.
summary: Internet Explorer (formerly Microsoft Internet Explorer and Windows Internet Explorer, commonly abbreviated as IE or MSIE) is  a deprecated (or discontinued for most modern Windows editions) series of graphical web browsers developed by Microsoft that were used in the Windows line of operating systems. While IE has been discontinued on most Windows editions, it remains supported on certain editions of Windows, such as Windows 10 LTSB/LTSC. Starting in 1995, it was first released as part of the add-on package Plus! for Windows 95 that year. Later versions were available as free downloads or in-service packs and included in the original equipment manufacturer (OEM) service releases of Windows 95 and later versions of Windows. Microsoft spent over US$100 million per year on Internet Explorer in the late 1990s, with over 1,000 people involved in the project by 1999.

document: iTunes revolutionized the way we consume and organize digital media. Originally announced by Apple CEO Steve Jobs in 2001, this software program has become a powerhouse in the world of media players. While its main focus was initially music, iTunes has evolved to include a wide range of features. It serves as a media library, allowing users to purchase, play, download, and organize digital multimedia. Not only can it be used on macOS and Windows operating systems, but it also serves as a mobile device management utility. With iTunes, users can rip songs from CDs and create dynamic, smart playlists. Furthermore, it offers options for sound optimizations and provides the ability to wirelessly share libraries. With its user-friendly interface and comprehensive features, iTunes continues to be a go-to platform for all things digital media.
noref_document: iTunes is a media player, media library, Internet radio broadcaster, and mobile device management application developed by Apple Inc. It was first released on January 9, 2001, and has since become one of the most popular software programs for managing digital media. iTunes allows users to organize and play their music and video files, purchase and download new content from the iTunes Store, and sync their media files with their Apple devices. With features such as a user-friendly interface and a vast library of music, movies, TV shows, podcasts, and more, iTunes has revolutionized the way people consume digital media.
summary:
iTunes () is a software program that acts as a media player, media library, mobile device management utility, and the client app for the iTunes Store. Developed by Apple Inc., it is used to purchase, play, download, and organize digital multimedia, on personal computers running the macOS and Windows operating systems, and can be used to rip songs from CDs, as well as play content with the use of dynamic, smart playlists. Options for sound optimizations exist, as well as ways to wirelessly share the iTunes library.
iTunes was originally announced by Apple CEO Steve Jobs on January 9, 2001. iTunes' original and main focus was music, with a library offering organization and storage of Mac users' music collections.

document: Adobe Flash Player, also known as Shockwave Flash in Internet Explorer, Firefox, and Google Chrome, is a computer software that allows users to view multimedia content, execute rich Internet applications, and stream audio and video content created on the Adobe Flash platform. It can be accessed through a web browser as a plug-in or can run independently on supported devices. Originally developed by FutureWave and known as FutureSplash Player, it was later renamed to Macromedia Flash Player after Macromedia acquired FutureWave in 1996. Following Adobe's acquisition of Macromedia in 2005, it became known as Flash Player, and is now developed and distributed by Zhongcheng for Chinese users, and by Harman International in partnership with Adobe for enterprise users outside of China.
noref_document: Adobe Flash Player is a multimedia software platform used for creating and displaying animations, browser games, and streaming video and audio. It was developed and distributed by Adobe Systems until its discontinuation in 2020. Flash Player was once a widely used plugin, enabling interactive multimedia content on various web browsers. However, with the rise of HTML5 technology, which offers better performance and security, Flash has become outdated and vulnerable to security exploits. As a result, major browser vendors have gradually phased out support for Flash, leading to its eventual discontinuation.
summary: Adobe Flash Player (known in Internet Explorer, Firefox, and Google Chrome as Shockwave Flash) is  computer software for viewing multimedia contents, executing rich Internet applications, and streaming audio and video content created on the Adobe Flash platform. It can run from a web browser as a browser plug-in or independently on supported devices. Originally created by FutureWave under the name FutureSplash Player, it was renamed to Macromedia Flash Player after Macromedia acquired FutureWave in 1996. It was then developed and distributed by Adobe Systems as Flash Player after Adobe acquired Macromedia in 2005. It is currently developed and distributed by Zhongcheng for users in China, and by Harman International for enterprise users outside of China, in collaboration with Adobe.

document: Google+, also known as Google Plus or G+, was a social network created by Google in 2011. It aimed to compete with other popular social networks by integrating various Google products such as YouTube, Blogger, and Google Drive. Initially, the platform experienced significant growth and had three Google executives overseeing its operations. However, user engagement and statistics fluctuated. In November 2015, Google+ underwent a major redesign. Unfortunately, due to low user engagement and security concerns regarding potential access to personal information by third-party developers, Google discontinued the Google+ developer API in March 2019. document: AOL Instant Messenger (AIM) was a widely-used instant messaging program in the late 1990s and early 2000s. It allowed registered users to communicate in real time using the OSCAR and TOC protocols. AIM gained popularity in the United States and other countries, becoming the leading instant messaging application in the region. Teens and college students often utilized the away message feature to keep in touch with friends, frequently changing their messages or leaving them up to inform others of their activities, location, parties, thoughts, or jokes. However, AIM's decline began as AOL subscribers decreased, and it further declined with the rise of Gmail's Google Talk, SMS, and social networks like Facebook. Its fall has been compared with other once-popular internet services like Myspace. In 2015, AOL was acquired by Verizon Communications.

Its fall has often been compared with other once-popular Internet services, such as Myspace.In June 2015, AOL was acquired by Verizon Communications.

document: The Sega Dreamcast, released in 1998 in Japan and later in other regions, marked an important era in the gaming industry as the first sixth-generation video game console. Developed by an internal Sega team led by Hideki Sato, the Dreamcast was designed with cost reduction in mind, utilizing off-the-shelf components such as a Hitachi SH-4 CPU and an NEC PowerVR2 GPU. To cut expenses, Sega opted for the GD-ROM media format instead of DVD-ROM technology. The Dreamcast ultimately became Sega's final console, bringing an end to the company's almost two-decade-long presence in the console market.

Despite its critical acclaim and cult following, the Dreamcast faced tough competition and struggled to compete with the PlayStation 2, ultimately leading to Sega discontinuing the console in 2001. It was the first sixth-generation video game console, preceding Sony's PlayStation 2, Nintendo's GameCube, and Microsoft's Xbox. The Dreamcast was Sega's final console; its 2001 discontinuation ended the company's eighteen years in the console market.
An internal Sega team led by Hideki Sato began developing the Dreamcast in 1997. In contrast to the expensive hardware of the unsuccessful Saturn, the Dreamcast was designed to reduce costs with off-the-shelf components, including a Hitachi SH-4 CPU and an NEC PowerVR2 GPU. Sega used the GD-ROM media format to avoid the expenses of DVD-ROM technology.

document: Kinect, developed by Microsoft, is a line of motion sensing devices that revolutionized the gaming industry when it was first released in 2010. Unlike its competitors, Kinect does not require physical controllers, making it a standout choice for gamers. Equipped with RGB cameras, infrared projectors, and detectors, Kinect calculates depth using structured light or time of flight calculations. This allows for real-time gesture recognition and body skeletal detection, enabling users to interact with games using their own bodies. In addition, Kinect includes microphones for speech recognition and voice control, enhancing the immersive gaming experience. Initially introduced as a peripheral for the Xbox 360 under the codename "Project Natal," Kinect has since gained popularity and expanded to be implemented in various fields beyond gaming.

Unlike traditional gaming controllers, Kinect uses an array of sensors to capture and track a player's body movements, allowing for a more immersive and intuitive gaming experience. In addition to gaming, Kinect also found applications in various fields such as healthcare, education, and robotics, where its motion tracking capabilities were used for gesture-based controls and motion analysis.
summary:
Kinect is a line of motion sensing input devices produced by Microsoft and first released in 2010. The devices generally contain RGB cameras, and infrared projectors and detectors that map depth through either structured light or time of flight calculations, which can in turn be used to perform real-time gesture recognition and body skeletal detection, among other capabilities. They also contain microphones that can be used for speech recognition and voice control.
Kinect was originally developed as a motion controller peripheral for Xbox video game consoles, distinguished from competitors (such as Nintendo's Wii Remote and Sony's PlayStation Move) by not requiring physical controllers. The first-generation Kinect was based on technology from Israeli company PrimeSense, and unveiled at E3 2009 as a peripheral for Xbox 360 codenamed "Project Natal".

document: The PlayStation Vita, also known as the PS Vita or Vita, is a handheld game console developed and marketed by Sony Interactive Entertainment. Released in 2011, it served as the successor to the PlayStation Portable and competes with the Nintendo 3DS. The original model features a 5-inch OLED touchscreen, analog joysticks, and various input options. It supports Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, and optional 3G connectivity. With a quad-core CPU and GPU, the Vita offers powerful performance. Sony later introduced the PS Vita 2000 series with a smaller size, extended battery life, and an LCD screen. Additionally, they released the PlayStation TV, a re-purposed version of the Vita that works like a home video game console. The Vita's design aimed to merge the experience of dedicated gaming platforms with the emerging trend of mobile gaming.

The original model of the handheld includes a 5-inch (130 mm) OLED multi-touch capacitive touchscreen, two analog joysticks, and front and shoulder push-button input, and supports Bluetooth, Wi-Fi, and optional 3G. The Vita's design was intended to meld the experience of big-budget, dedicated video game platforms with the then up-and-coming trend of mobile gaming as seen on smart phones and tablets.

document: The Samsung Galaxy Note 7, unveiled in August 2016, was a highly anticipated Android phablet. document: Lytro, Inc., a pioneering American company founded by Ren Ng in 2006, revolutionized the world of photography with its groundbreaking light-field cameras. document: The Virtual Boy, developed and manufactured by Nintendo, is a 32-bit tabletop portable video game console that was released in 1995. Marketed as the first console capable of displaying stereoscopic "3D" graphics, it revolutionized the gaming experience. By placing the head against the eyepiece, players could see a vivid red monochrome display that enhanced the visual appeal. The games utilized a remarkable parallax effect, which ingeniously created the illusion of depth. Despite the initial anticipation, sales of the Virtual Boy failed to meet expectations. Nintendo made the difficult decision to halt distribution and game development in 1996, ultimately releasing only 22 games for this groundbreaking system.

document: 3D television, also known as 3DTV, revolutionized the way viewers experienced television by providing an enhanced sense of depth perception. This technology utilized various techniques like stereoscopic display, multi-view display, and 2D-plus-depth to create a three-dimensional visual experience. Initially, most 3D TV sets used active shutter or polarized 3D systems, while some were even autostereoscopic, eliminating the need for glasses. However, as of 2017, the availability of 3D TV sets and services from manufacturers has significantly declined, indicating a shift in consumer demand and evolving technology trends.
noref_document: 3D television, a technology that has gained popularity in recent years, refers to the transmission of stereoscopic images to provide viewers with a three-dimensional visual experience. By utilizing various techniques such as polarized glasses or active shutter glasses, 3D TV allows for depth perception, immersing viewers in a more realistic and captivating environment. This innovative technology has been used in various fields including entertainment, gaming, and education, revolutionizing the way we engage with visual media. Despite its initial buzz, the adoption of 3D television has faced challenges due to high costs, the need for compatible content, and issues related to viewer discomfort. However, continuous advancements in display technology and the rise of virtual reality have contributed to the further exploration and development of 3D television, ensuring its continued presence and potential future impact in the entertainment industry.
summary:
3D television (3DTV) is television that conveys depth perception to the viewer by employing techniques such as stereoscopic display, multi-view display, 2D-plus-depth, or any other form of 3D display. Most modern 3D television sets use an active shutter 3D system or a polarized 3D system, and some are autostereoscopic without the need of glasses. As of 2017, most 3D TV sets and services are no longer available from manufacturers.


== History ==

The stereoscope was first invented by Sir Charles Wheatstone in 1838. It showed that when two pictures are viewed stereoscopically,  they are combined by the brain to produce 3D depth perception.

document: Voyager 1, a space probe launched by NASA on September 5, 1977, is currently the most distant human-made object from Earth. Having operated for an impressive 46 years and 14 days, it forms a crucial part of the Voyager program designed to explore the outer Solar System and interstellar space beyond the Sun's heliosphere. Communicating through the NASA Deep Space Network, Voyager 1 receives routine commands and transmits valuable data back to Earth. At a distance of 161 AU (24 billion km; 15 billion mi) from Earth as of August 2023, this remarkable probe has completed flybys of Jupiter, Saturn, and Saturn's largest moon, Titan. The choice to prioritize the Titan flyby over Pluto was made due to the former's substantial atmosphere, making it an intriguing subject for exploration.

At a distance of 161 AU (24 billion km; 15 billion mi) from Earth as of August 2023, it is the most distant human-made object from Earth.The probe made flybys of Jupiter, Saturn, and Saturn's largest moon, Titan. NASA had a choice of either doing a Pluto or Titan flyby; exploration of the moon took priority because it was known to have a substantial atmosphere.

document: Voyager 2, a space probe launched by NASA on August 20, 1977, embarked on an extraordinary journey to explore the outer planets and venture beyond the boundaries of the Sun's heliosphere into interstellar space. Alongside its twin, Voyager 1, it was a part of the ambitious Voyager program. Unlike its sibling, Voyager 2 took a longer trajectory to reach gas giants Jupiter and Saturn but was rewarded with further encounters with the ice giants Uranus and Neptune. Remarkably, Voyager 2 remains the only spacecraft to have ever visited either of these intriguing ice giant planets. Demonstrating its incredible capability, Voyager 2 achieved Solar escape velocity, becoming the third of only five spacecraft to venture beyond the boundaries of our Solar System. During its mission, Voyager 2 successfully fulfilled its primary objective, providing valuable insights into the Jovian, Saturnian, Uranian, and Neptunian systems, unveiling captivating discoveries about these distant worlds.

Voyager 2 has achieved significant milestones in space exploration, becoming the first spacecraft to provide detailed images of Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune. It has also provided valuable data about the outer planets and their moons, shedding light on their atmospheric composition, magnetic fields, and ring systems. After more than four decades, Voyager 2 continues to travel through interstellar space, providing scientists with invaluable insights into the far reaches of our solar system.
summary:
Voyager 2 is a space probe launched by NASA on August 20, 1977, to study the outer planets and interstellar space beyond the Sun's heliosphere. As a part of the Voyager program, it was launched 16 days before its twin, Voyager 1, on a trajectory that took longer to reach gas giants Jupiter and Saturn but enabled further encounters with ice giants Uranus and Neptune. Voyager 2 remains the only spacecraft to have visited either of the ice giant planets. Voyager 2 was the third of five spacecraft to achieve Solar escape velocity, which allowed it to leave the Solar System.
Voyager 2 successfully fulfilled its primary mission of visiting the Jovian system in 1979, the Saturnian system in 1981, Uranian system in 1986, and the Neptunian system in 1989.

document: Apollo 11, the American spaceflight that successfully landed humans on the Moon, remains an iconic moment in history. In July 1969, Commander Neil Armstrong and Lunar Module Pilot Buzz Aldrin achieved this incredible feat by landing the Apollo Lunar Module Eagle on the lunar surface. Armstrong emerged as the first person to step foot on the Moon, followed by Aldrin shortly after. Together, they spent over two hours venturing around Tranquility Base, the landing site they had named. During their mission, they collected a remarkable 47.5 pounds (21.5 kg) of lunar material to bring back to Earth. Meanwhile, pilot Michael Collins manned the Command Module Columbia, which orbited the Moon. In total, Armstrong and Aldrin spent approximately 21 hours and 36 minutes on the Moon's surface before beginning their journey back to the Command Module. The Apollo 11 spacecraft, launched by a Saturn V rocket from Kennedy Space Center in Florida, consisted of three components: a command module that returned the astronauts to Earth, a service module that provided vital support, and a lunar module with two stages for landing and ascent. The historic mission of Apollo 11 exemplified humanity's spirit of exploration and marked a significant milestone in space exploration.
noref_document: Apollo 11 was the famous space mission that landed the first humans on the Moon. Launched by NASA in 1969, Apollo 11 took an 8-day journey, commanded by Neil Armstrong. The spacecraft carried a three-person crew, including Buzz Aldrin and Michael Collins. On July 20, 1969, Neil Armstrong became the first person to step onto the lunar surface, famously declaring, "That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind." The mission successfully completed its objectives and returned safely to Earth, marking a significant milestone in space exploration and sparking a renewed interest in the possibilities of human space travel.
summary:
Apollo 11 (July 16–24, 1969) was the American spaceflight that first landed humans on the Moon. Commander Neil Armstrong and Lunar Module Pilot Buzz Aldrin landed the Apollo Lunar Module Eagle on July 20, 1969, at 20:17 UTC, and Armstrong became the first person to step onto the Moon's surface six hours and 39 minutes later, on July 21 at 02:56 UTC. Aldrin joined him 19 minutes later, and they spent about two and a quarter hours together exploring the site they had named Tranquility Base upon landing. Armstrong and Aldrin collected 47.5 pounds (21.5 kg) of lunar material to bring back to Earth as pilot Michael Collins flew the Command Module Columbia in lunar orbit, and were on the Moon's surface for 21 hours, 36 minutes before lifting off to rejoin Columbia.
Apollo 11 was launched by a Saturn V rocket from Kennedy Space Center on Merritt Island, Florida, on July 16 at 13:32 UTC, and it was the fifth crewed mission of NASA's Apollo program. The Apollo spacecraft had three parts: a command module (CM) with a cabin for the three astronauts, the only part that returned to Earth; a service module (SM), which supported the command module with propulsion, electrical power, oxygen, and water; and a lunar module (LM) that had two stages—a descent stage for landing on the Moon and an ascent stage to place the astronauts back into lunar orbit.

document: Pioneer 10, the NASA space probe launched in 1972, holds the prestigious title of completing the first-ever mission to the planet Jupiter. Not only that, but this remarkable spacecraft also became the pioneer among five planetary probes and eleven artificial objects to successfully attain the escape velocity necessary to venture beyond the boundaries of our Solar System. With its roots at the NASA Ames Research Center in California, Pioneer 10 was specially crafted by TRW Inc. The spacecraft's design revolved around a hexagonal bus, hosting an impressive parabolic dish high-gain antenna measuring a diameter of 2.74 meters (9 ft 0 in). Thanks to its spin stabilization mechanism centered on the axis of the antenna, Pioneer 10 embarked on an extraordinary journey of space exploration.
noref_document: Pioneer 10, launched in 1972, was the first spacecraft to travel through the asteroid belt and study Jupiter up close. This pioneering space probe gathered valuable data about the largest planet in our solar system, including its atmosphere, magnetic field, and moons. It also provided us with stunning close-up images of Jupiter, providing scientists with crucial insights about its turbulent atmosphere and stormy surface. Although it has since ceased communication with Earth, Pioneer 10 remains a testament to human curiosity and exploration, paving the way for future deep space missions.
summary:
Pioneer 10 (originally designated Pioneer F) is a NASA space probe launched in 1972 that completed the first mission to the planet Jupiter. Pioneer 10 became the first of five planetary probes and 11 artificial objects to achieve the escape velocity needed to leave the Solar System. This space exploration project was conducted by the NASA Ames Research Center in California. The space probe was manufactured by TRW Inc.
Pioneer 10 was assembled around a hexagonal bus with a 2.74-meter (9 ft 0 in) diameter parabolic dish high-gain antenna, and the spacecraft was spin stabilized around the axis of the antenna.

document: Mariner 4, also known as Mariner-Mars 1964, was a pioneering spacecraft in the field of planetary exploration. Launched on November 28, 1964, its primary objective was to conduct closeup scientific observations of Mars and transmit them back to Earth. This mission marked a significant milestone as it became the first spacecraft to successfully flyby Mars, capturing and returning the first close-up images of the Martian surface. These images were a game-changer, revealing a cratered and lifeless planet, thus reshaping the scientific community's understanding of Mars' potential for sustaining life. document: The Galileo spacecraft, named after the renowned Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei, was an American robotic space probe that embarked on a remarkable mission to study the planet Jupiter and its moons. document: Voyager 2, a space probe launched by NASA on August 20, 1977, embarked on an extraordinary mission to explore the outer planets and venture into interstellar space beyond the Sun's heliosphere. As part of the Voyager program, it was sent off 16 days ahead of its twin, Voyager 1, following a trajectory that required more time to reach gas giants Jupiter and Saturn but allowed for unprecedented encounters with ice giants Uranus and Neptune. In fact, Voyager 2 still holds the distinction of being the only spacecraft to have ever visited these mesmerizing ice giant planets. As a pioneer in space exploration, Voyager 2 became the third out of five spacecraft to achieve Solar escape velocity, granting it the ability to leave our Solar System. Throughout its journey, Voyager 2 successfully completed its primary mission, visiting the Jovian system in 1979, the Saturnian system in 1981, the Uranian system in 1986, and accomplished its grand finale by exploring the Neptunian system in 1989. Its remarkable accomplishments have provided us with invaluable knowledge about the outer reaches of our celestial neighborhood.

document: The year 2000 problem, also known as the Y2K problem or millennium bug, was a computer issue that arose due to the incorrect formatting and storage of calendar data for dates in and after the year 2000. Many programs represented four-digit years with only the final two digits, which meant that the year 2000 would be interpreted as 1900. This potential error had significant implications for computer-reliant industries worldwide. In the years leading up to the millennium, the general public became increasingly aware of the Y2K scare. Companies estimated that rectifying the bug would cost anywhere between $400 million and $600 billion. The lack of clarity surrounding the bug's potential dangers led some individuals to stockpile essentials, buy firearms, and withdraw large amounts of money. Despite these fears, few major errors actually occurred in 2000.
noref_document: The Year 2000 problem, also known as the Y2K bug, was a significant concern in the late 1990s leading up to the new millennium. It revolved around computer systems and software applications that represented years with only two digits, causing potential issues when the year 2000 would be interpreted as 1900 instead. Organizations worldwide embarked on extensive efforts to fix this problem before the clock struck midnight on January 1, 2000. These preparations involved debugging and updating computer systems, testing software for Y2K compatibility, and implementing contingency plans to mitigate potential disruptions. Despite initial fears of widespread chaos, the concerted global effort succeeded, and the new millennium arrived without major Y2K-related problems.
summary:
The year 2000 problem, also commonly known as the Y2K problem, Y2K scare, millennium bug, Y2K bug, Y2K glitch, Y2K error, or simply Y2K refers to potential computer errors related to the formatting and storage of calendar data for dates in and after the year 2000. Many programs represented four-digit years with only the final two digits, making the year 2000 indistinguishable from 1900. Computer systems' inability to distinguish dates correctly had the potential to bring down worldwide infrastructures for computer reliant industries.
In the years leading up to the turn of the century (millennium), the public gradually became aware of the "Y2K scare", and individual companies predicted the global damage caused by the bug would require anything between $400 million and $600 billion to rectify. A lack of clarity regarding the potential dangers of the bug led some to stock up on food, water, and firearms, purchase backup generators, and withdraw large sums of money in anticipation of a computer-induced apocalypse.Contrary to published expectations, few major errors occurred in 2000.

document: The solar eclipse of August 21, 2017, known as the "Great American Eclipse," captivated millions of people across the United States and beyond. This celestial phenomenon offered a unique opportunity for Americans to witness a total solar eclipse, as it created a remarkable path that extended from the Pacific to the Atlantic coast. Crowds gathered in cities and towns along this path to experience the awe-inspiring moment when the moon completely blocked the sun, casting a shadow over the landscape. The eclipse was not limited to the United States; it was visible from Canada's Nunavut region in the north to as far south as northern South America. Even in northwestern Europe, Africa, and northeastern Asia, people were able to catch a glimpse of this extraordinary event––their evening or morning skies graced by a partial eclipse. This historic occurrence truly brought people from around the world together to witness the magnificent beauty of our universe.
noref_document: The Solar Eclipse of August 21, 2017, also known as the "Great American Eclipse," was a remarkable celestial event that captivated millions of people across North America. This rare total solar eclipse traversed a path across the United States from the West Coast to the East Coast, providing a unique opportunity for countless skywatchers to witness the moon fully blocking the sun, creating a breathtaking display of darkness in the middle of the day. Many communities within the path of totality organized special events and viewing parties, bringing together people from all walks of life to marvel at this extraordinary cosmic phenomenon. As the first total solar eclipse visible in the contiguous United States since 1979, it sparked excitement and fascination, with professionals and amateur astronomers alike preparing to capture the event through telescopes, cameras, and special viewing glasses. Overall, the Solar Eclipse of August 21, 2017, brought together individuals from different backgrounds to share in the wonderment of our universe and served as a reminder of the awe-inspiring power of nature.
summary:
The solar eclipse of August 21, 2017, dubbed the "Great American Eclipse" by some media, was a total solar eclipse visible within a band that spanned the contiguous United States from the Pacific to the Atlantic coasts. It was also visible as a partial solar eclipse from as far north as Nunavut in northern Canada to as far south as northern South America. In northwestern Europe and Africa, it was partially visible in the late evening. In northeastern Asia, it was partially visible at sunrise.

Prior to this event, no solar eclipse had been visible across the entirety of the United States since June 8, 1918; not since the February 1979 eclipse had a total eclipse been visible from anywhere in the mainland United States.

document: The 2016 United States presidential election will forever be remembered as a historic moment in American politics. Against all odds, Republican candidate Donald Trump and his running mate Mike Pence secured a victory over the Democratic ticket of Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine. The election itself was filled with surprises and controversies, with Trump's unconventional campaign style attracting significant media attention. Utilizing a right-wing populist and nationalist platform, Trump promised to "Make America Great Again" and criticized issues such as political correctness, illegal immigration, and free-trade agreements. Clinton, on the other hand, became the first female presidential nominee of a major American political party, solidifying her position as a trailblazer in American history. The election showcased the divisions within the country and marked the end of President Barack Obama's tenure, as he was ineligible to pursue a third term according to the Twenty-second Amendment to the US Constitution. document: Pioneer 10, a NASA space probe launched in 1972 by the Ames Research Center in California, embarked on a historic mission to Jupiter. document: MESSENGER, a NASA robotic space probe, successfully orbited the planet Mercury between 2011 and 2015. It conducted an extensive study of Mercury's chemical composition, geology, and magnetic field. The spacecraft's name is derived from the acronym "Mercury Surface, Space Environment, Geochemistry, and Ranging," and pays homage to the messenger god Mercury from Roman mythology. MESSENGER was launched into space aboard a Delta II rocket in August 2004. Its trajectory incorporated a series of flybys, including Earth, Venus, and Mercury itself, to decelerate relative to Mercury while using minimal fuel. With its flyby of Mercury in January 2008, it became the second mission to reach the planet after Mariner 10 in 1975. Finally, MESSENGER successfully entered orbit around Mercury on March 18, 2011, marking a significant milestone as the first spacecraft to achieve such a feat.

During its mission, MESSENGER discovered evidence of water ice on Mercury's poles, which was a surprising finding considering the planet's proximity to the Sun. MESSENGER also observed complex geological features such as giant cliffs and volcanic plains, which gave scientists insights into the planet's history and formation. This mission significantly expanded our knowledge and understanding of Mercury and its unique characteristics.

During its first flyby of Mercury in January 2008, MESSENGER became the second mission, after Mariner 10 in 1975, to reach Mercury.MESSENGER entered orbit around Mercury on March 18, 2011, becoming the first spacecraft to do so.

document: Stardust, a 385-kilogram robotic space probe launched by NASA in 1999, embarked on an extraordinary mission that revolutionized our understanding of comets and cosmic dust. Its primary objective was to collect dust samples from the coma of comet Wild 2 and cosmic dust, and bring them back to Earth for analysis. This groundbreaking endeavor marked the first-ever sample return mission of its kind. Along its journey to comet Wild 2, Stardust also made a significant detour to study the asteroid 5535 Annefrank. After a successful completion of its primary mission in January 2006, the spacecraft embarked on a mission extension known as NExT. This exciting continuation culminated in 2011 when Stardust intercepted comet Tempel 1, a small Solar System body that had previously been visited by the Deep Impact mission in 2005. Through its remarkable voyages and invaluable samples, Stardust expanded our knowledge of celestial bodies and contributed to numerous scientific breakthroughs.

The spacecraft returned to Earth in 2006, delivering its precious cargo to scientists who continue to analyze and study these cosmic samples, providing valuable insights into the origins and nature of our solar system.

document: The 2012 phenomenon refers to a series of eschatological beliefs that foresaw cataclysmic or transformative events taking place around 21 December 2012. This specific date was considered the end of a 5,126-year-long cycle in the Mesoamerican Long Count calendar. To celebrate this event, festivities were held in countries associated with the Maya civilization, such as Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador. The main commemorative events took place at Chichén Itzá in Mexico and Tikal in Guatemala. Numerous astronomical alignments and numerological formulae were proposed for this date, sparking various interpretations. Among them, a New Age perspective saw 21 December 2012 as the start of a period of positive transformation for Earth and its inhabitants, while others believed it signaled the end of the world or a similar catastrophic event. Speculations for the world's end ranged from the next solar maximum, interactions between Earth and Sagittarius A* (the supermassive black hole at the center of the galaxy), the Nibiru cataclysm involving a mythical planet crashing into Earth, or even the heating of Earth's core.

While some individuals feared a doomsday scenario or catastrophic events, others saw it as a time of spiritual transformation and consciousness awakening. Despite the excitement and anticipation leading up to the date, December 21, 2012, passed without any noteworthy apocalyptic incidents, highlighting the range of interpretations and theories associated with the 2012 phenomenon.
summary: The 2012 phenomenon was a range of eschatological beliefs that cataclysmic or transformative events would occur on or around 21 December 2012. This date was regarded as the end-date of a 5,126-year-long cycle in the Mesoamerican Long Count calendar, and festivities took place on 21 December 2012 to commemorate the event in the countries that were part of the Maya civilization (Mexico, Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador), with main events at Chichén Itzá in Mexico and Tikal in Guatemala.Various astronomical alignments and numerological formulae were proposed for this date. A New Age interpretation held that the date marked the start of a period during which Earth and its inhabitants would undergo a positive physical or spiritual transformation, and that 21 December 2012 would mark the beginning of a new era. Others suggested that the date marked the end of the world or a similar catastrophe. document: The 2008 Summer Olympics, officially known as the Games of the XXIX Olympiad, were a remarkable international multisport event held in Beijing, China, from 8 to 24 August 2008. It was the first time China had hosted the Olympic Games and marked the third occurrence of the Summer Olympics in East Asia. With 10,942 athletes representing 204 National Olympic Committees, the event showcased the talents and skills of athletes competing in 28 sports and 302 events, one more than the previous Olympics. Beijing's successful bid to host the Games was announced on 13 July 2001 after winning the majority of votes from the International Olympic Committee. This historical event contributed to the rich Olympic heritage of both China and East Asia, while also highlighting the global unity and celebration of sport.

These Olympics attracted worldwide attention, not only due to the outstanding performances of athletes like Michael Phelps, but also because of China's rich cultural heritage and technological innovations on display during the opening and closing ceremonies. The 2008 Summer Olympics left a lasting legacy for Beijing and highlighted the country's ability to host major international events.
summary:
The 2008 Summer Olympics (Chinese: 2008年夏季奥运会; pinyin: Èr Líng Líng Bā Nián Xiàjì Àoyùnhuì), officially the Games of the XXIX Olympiad (Chinese: 第二十九届夏季奥林匹克运动会; pinyin: Dì Èrshíjiǔ Jiè Xiàjì Àolínpǐkè Yùndònghuì) and also known as Beijing 2008 (Chinese: 北京2008; pinyin: Běijīng èr líng líng bā), were an international multisport event held from 8 to 24 August 2008, in Beijing, China. A total of 10,942 athletes from 204 National Olympic Committees (NOCs) competed in 28 sports and 302 events, one event more than those scheduled for the 2004 Summer Olympics. This was the first time China had hosted the Olympic Games, and the third time the Summer Olympic Games had been held in East Asia, following the 1964 Olympics in Tokyo, Japan, and the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea. These were also the second Summer Olympic Games to be held in a communist state, the first being the 1980 Summer Olympics in the Soviet Union (with venues in Russia, Ukraine, Byelorussia, and Estonia).
Beijing was awarded the 2008 Games over four competitors on 13 July 2001, having won a majority of votes from members of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) after two rounds of voting.
